awd_titl_txt: Experimental Study of Pressure-induced Structural Changes in Silicate Glasses to >100 GPa
awd_abstract_narration:
Silicate magmas are the most efficient carriers of heat and matter throughout Earth's reservoirs, and play an important role in a wide range of geological processes.  Silicate magmas are high pressure objects, formed at depth in the present Earth beneath volcanoes, mid-ocean ridges, subduction zones, and hotspots, or in the deep magma ocean in the early Earth.  Silicate magmas undergo structural changes at high pressure conditions, and knowledge of the pressure-induced structural changes in silicate magmas is important to understand behavior of silicate magmas in the Earth's deep interior.  The investigator developed new double-stage high-pressure apparatus combined with synchrotron X-ray measurement, to study pressure-induced structural changes in silicate glasses, which is an analogue material of silicate magmas, at high pressure conditions to >100 GPa corresponding to the lowermost part of the Earth's mantle.   Establishing the new high-pressure experimental technique in a user facility (the beamline 16-BM-B, HPCAT in the Advanced Photon Source) contributes to researches not only in Earth and planetary sciences but also in various scientific fields such as physics and material sciences as well as engineering, and to educational activities for graduate students and young postdoctoral researchers.

This project aims to experimentally investigate pressure-induced structural changes in SiO2 and silicate glasses at high pressure conditions to >100 GPa.  Large volume sample is vital for accurate measurement of the structure of silicate glasses at high pressure conditions using X-ray diffraction measurement.  The investigator developed a new double-stage Paris-Edinburgh type large volume press to generate high pressures to >100 GPa with large sample volume.  Structure of silicate glasses will be measured by in situ multi-angle energy dispersive X-ray diffraction at high pressures.  This project will provide vital experimental constraints on understanding pressure-induced structural changes in silicate magmas at the pressure conditions of the Earth's deep mantle to the core-mantle boundary by (1) obtaining the first experimental data for structure of silicate glasses to >100 GPa, and (2) establishing relationship between Si-O coordination number and oxygen packing fraction to generalize the pressure-induced structural changes in silicate glasses for application to silicate magmas in the Earth?s deep interior.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Pressure-induced structural changes in silicate melts are one of the most important issues to understand behavior of silicate magmas at the Earth's deep interior. It is known that structure of SiO2 glass changes from four-fold coordinated structure to six-fold coordinated structure around the pressure condition of the Earth's lower mantle. In addition, it is found that structure of GeO2 glass, which is an analogue of SiO2 glass, further changes from six-fold coordinated structure to a structure with coordination number (CN) higher than six. The possible existence of the CN>6 structure in silicate melt and glass is predicted at >100 GPa by theoretical studies. Our research revealed direct experimental evidence of CN(Si)>6 in SiO2 glass at pressures above 106 GPa, using our recently developed opposed type double-stage large volume cell. Considering similarities in pressure-induced structural changes between SiO2 glass and silicate melts, the structural results of SiO2 glass imply that silicate melts with CN(Si)>6 structures may have higher densities than silicate minerals which have CN(Si)=6 throughout the Earth?s mantle. Hence, from the local structure point of view, this study supports the view that silicate melts can be gravitationally stable in the deep mantle. We further investigated the structure of MgSiO?3 glass up to pressures above 100 GPa and found evidence for a structure change at 88 GPa (equivalent to ~2000-km depth in Earth?s mantle). The pressure of the structural change is broadly consistent with or slightly lower than that of the bridgmanite-to-postperovskite transition in crystalline MgSiO3. Considering structural similarities between MgSiO3 glass and MgSiO3 melt, these results suggest that a structural change in MgSiO3 melt might also occur under pressure conditions corresponding to the deep lower mantle, which is important for understanding silicate liquid behavior in the deep Earth.

Broader Impacts: Knowledge on pressure-induced structural changes in network-forming glasses is of great interest not only in geophysics, but also in various scientific fields such as condensed matter physics and materials sciences as well as in engineering and industry. SiO2 and silicate glasses are one of the prototype network-forming glasses. Experimental investigation of the structural changes in these glasses provide important knowledge on understanding systematic structural changes in network-forming glasses and fundamental information to predict and control structure and the resultant physical properties of network-forming glasses and melts with broad scientific and engineering applications. In addition, the established new technique for structure measurement of glass at extreme pressure in a user facility (the beamline 16-BM-B, HPCAT in the Advanced Photon Source) has contributed research and educational activities in wide range of communities not only in earth and planetary sciences but also in physics, material sciences, and engineering. About 60% of HPCAT users are graduate students and young postdoctoral researchers. The project provided training for postdocs and visitors who gained critical skills for their career development.
